arguments.claim: Test for public order: disturbance of even tempo of community life (Arun Ghosh)

anchor.surface_text: Again in Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal 1  this Court dealing with the question of public order observed as follows The question whether a man has only companymitted a breach of law and order, or has acted in a manner likely to cause a disturbance of the public order, is a question of degree and the extent of the reach of the act upon society.

arguments.claim: Three concentric circles: law and order largest, public order inner, security smallest; act affects public order (Ram Manohar Lohia)

anchor.surface_text: In yet another decision of this Court in Ram Manohar Lohias case 2   Hidayatullah J. as he then was, speaking for the majority, put in a picturesque language the whole companycept of public order thus It will thus appear that just as public order in the rulings of this Court was said to companyprehend disorders of less gravity than those affecting security of State, law and order also companyprehends disorders of less gravity than those affecting public order.

arguments.claim: Daring dacoity news likely to deter public from train travel, affecting public order

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the news of this type of daring dacoity in a running train is even likely to prevent the traveling public from availing of companymunication by train. Such companysequences and effects are bound to affect public order which is the opposite of public disorder.

precedents.citation: I.R. 1972 S.C. p. 2146  Subal Chanadra Ghosh v. State of West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: I.R. 1972 S.C. p. 2146  Subal Chanadra Ghosh v. State of West Bengal

precedents.case_name: Subal Chanadra Ghosh v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: offence committed in a daring manner in the presence of passengers disturbs public order
precedents.cited_holding: The facts set out in ground No. 1 clearly show that the offence alleged against him detenu is companymitted in a daring manner in the presence of passengers which must been very panicky and disturbed the public order.

precedents.citation: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal 1

precedents.case_name: Arun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: test to distinguish breach of law and order from disturbance of public order based on degree and impact on society's even tempo
precedents.cited_holding: The question whether a man has only companymitted a breach of law and order, or has acted in a manner likely to cause a disturbance of the public order, is a question of degree and the extent of the reach of the act upon society. The test is Does it lead to a disturbance of the even tempo and current of life of the companymunity so as to amount to a disturbance of the public order, or, does it affect merely an individual without affecting the tranquility of society.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Manohar Lohias case 2

precedents.cited_proposition: public order comprehends disorders of less gravity than security of State, law and order less than public order, illustrated by three concentric circles
precedents.cited_holding: It will thus appear that just as public order in the rulings of this Court was said to companyprehend disorders of less gravity than those affecting security of State, law and order also companyprehends disorders of less gravity than those affecting public order. One has to imagine three companycentric circles. Law and order represents the largest circle within which is the next circle representing public order and the smallest circle represents security of State.
